title: Growing Oleanders from Cuttings: Tips and Advice

steps.title: Take 4 to 6-inch tip cuttings.
steps.content: Take 4 to 6-inch tip cuttings. The cuttings should not be "busy" with leaves. There should also be no flowers or flower buds on the cutting. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Strip the lower (cut end) half to 2/3 of the cutting's leaves off.
steps.content: Strip the lower (cut end) half to 2/3 of the cutting's leaves off.

steps.title: Cut the remaining leaves to half length.
steps.content: Cut the remaining leaves to half length. This helps encourage root formation in the next step. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Get a small clear glass jar and add an inch or two of water to the bottom.
steps.content: Get a small clear glass jar and add an inch or two of water to the bottom. Place the cut end of the cuttings in the water, and keep in a shady spot indoors. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Add small amounts of water to the jar as needed to replace water lost to evaporation.
steps.content: Add small amounts of water to the jar as needed to replace water lost to evaporation. Just try to keep the water level about the same.

steps.title: In 2 - 3 weeks, rooting should occur.
steps.content: In 2 - 3 weeks, rooting should occur. Early signs of rooting include the formation of a couple small bumps or bulges on the stem, just below the lowest set of leaf nodes. Once these bumps occur, rooting will occur shortly after.

steps.title: Once the roots reach about 1/2 to 1 inch long (this will happen very quickly once roots have started forming), plant it in a pot filled with potting mix, at about the same depth as the water line was on the cutting.
steps.content: Once the roots reach about 1/2 to 1 inch long (this will happen very quickly once roots have started forming), plant it in a pot filled with potting mix, at about the same depth as the water line was on the cutting.

steps.title: Give it water right away, and keep watered, but make sure it drains well.
steps.content: Give it water right away, and keep watered, but make sure it drains well.

steps.title: In about a year, it will be big enough to be repotted into a gallon-size pot.
steps.content: In about a year, it will be big enough to be repotted into a gallon-size pot.

steps.title: Continue with repotting as needed, or if you live in USDA Planting Zone 9 - 11, plant in the ground.
steps.content: Continue with repotting as needed, or if you live in USDA Planting Zone 9 - 11, plant in the ground. If you live north of zone 9, keep your oleander in a pot indoors in the winter, as winter temperatures in those climates will kill it. [4] X Research source
